elements.content: The present work reports the synthesis, characterization, and crystal structure of a neutral two-dimensional adenine-based luminescent coordination polymer (LCP) with Zn­(II) metal nodes. The photoluminescence property of the d10 LCP [Zn­(μ2-1H-ade)­(μ2-SO4)] (1) has been exploited to use 1 as a dual detection probe for the selective sensing of Hg2+ and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) in the aqueous phase from among a variety of cations and a pool of aromatic nitro compounds, respectively. Competitive fluorometric experiments involving a series of cation combinations or mixture of nitro compounds established 1 as an efficient and selective sensor for Hg2+ and TNP in aqueous solutions. The limits of detection for sensing of Hg2+ and TNP in aqueous solutions using LCP 1 are 70 and 0.4 nM, respectively. For in-field sensing applications, 1-coated test paper strips have been developed. They show luminescence upon exposure to UV radiation, and the luminescence intensity is quenched upon addition to aqueous solutions of the target analytes. The present investigation clearly demonstrates selective, recyclable detection of lethal environmental pollutants such as Hg2+ and TNP in aqueous media, which has relevance in the context of environmental protection and homeland security.

elements.content: A two-dimensional adenine-based Zn­(II) luminescent coordination polymer (LCP) showing good thermal and chemical stability has been synthesized and characterized by various analytical methods, including single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Functional aspects of LCP 1 as a potential chemosensor for selective detection of Hg2+ and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol in aqueous media as well as by a paper strip method have been explored.

elements.content: As a result of extensive industrialization, water contamination and environmental problems have become major issues, as large volumes of effluents with high concentrations of heavy-metal ions and toxic organic pollutants are being discharged into bodies of water. The detection of toxic metal ions and organic pollutants such as nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) has always been an important challenge regarding environmental protection, human health, homeland security, and safety. Mercury­(II) is one of the significant metal pollutants since it is toxic to human health and poses a threat to the environment. For potable water, maximum permitted Hg2+ levels of 10 and 30 nM are regulated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the World Health Organization (WHO), respectively. The presence and accumulation of Hg2+ in the human body even at a low concentration can cause different diseases related to the digestive, neurological, and excretory systems. On the other hand, nitroaromatic compounds should not be neglected as a class of toxic and hazardous chemicals. Selective and sensitive detection of explosives or explosive-like substances has become one of the challenging issues in recent times. Chemical constituents of commercial explosives include NACs such as 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP). TNP is not only a strong explosive but also used extensively in dyes, fireworks, and the pharmaceutical and leather industries. Eventually alarming amounts of TNP are released to the environment by these industries as effluents.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As a result of extensive industrialization, water contamination and environmental problems have become major issues, as large volumes of effluents with high concentrations of heavy-metal ions and toxic organic pollutants are being discharged into bodies of water. The detection of toxic metal ions and organic pollutants such as nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) has always been an important challenge regarding environmental protection, human health, homeland security, and safety. Mercury(II) is one of the significant metal pollutants since it is toxic to human health and poses a threat to the environment. For potable water, maximum permitted Hg2+ levels of 10 and 30 nM are regulated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the World Health Organization (WHO), respectively. The presence and accumulation of Hg2+ in the human body even at a low concentration can cause different diseases related to the digestive, neurological, and excretory systems. On the other hand, nitroaromatic compounds should not be neglected as a class of toxic and hazardous chemicals. Selective and sensitive detection of explosives or explosive-like substances has become one of the challenging issues in recent times. Chemical constituents of commercial explosives include NACs such as 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP). TNP is not only a strong explosive but also used extensively in dyes, fireworks, and the pharmaceutical and leather industries. Eventually alarming amounts of TNP are released to the environment by these industries as effluents.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks/coordination polymers (MOFs/CPs) are emerging materials fabricated from metal nodes/clusters linked by organic ligands to generate multidimensional frameworks. MOFs/CPs have been identified not only for their aesthetic structural topologies but also for diverse applications in the areas of heterogeneous catalysis, gas storage, gas separation, drug delivery, and molecular sensing. In recent times, the design and synthesis of luminescent coordination polymers (LCPs) have gained enormous attention for the selective and sensitive detection of different toxic metal ions and harmful organic pollutants that are discharged to the environment as industrial effluents. The detection and removal of toxic heavy metal ions and harmful NACs in wastewater and drinking water distribution are requisites from the health and security viewpoint. This has prompted researchers toward the development of simple, user-friendly, and cost-effective methods to selectively detect and quantify them, preferably in the aqueous phase. A convenient, effective, and rapid method for the detection and quantification of Hg2+/NACs in water has thus become one of the top research priorities. It remains a challenge to develop LCP-based sensors for the selective detection of Hg2+ and TNP in the aqueous phase by exploiting the fluorescence property. Lanthanide and d10 metal node-based luminescent metal–organic frameworks (LMOFs) have emerged as tunable luminescent sensors for chemical species. On the basis of the electron-deficient characteristic of NACs and the photoinduced electron transfer (PET) quenching mechanism, LMOFs/LCPs have been designed as efficient fluorescent chemosensors for the detection of NACs in the vapor/liquid phase because of their good sensitivity, ease of operation, and visualization. Luminescence-based methods have been widely used for sensing and detection of TNP, and a few luminescent sensors for the detection of Hg2+ have also been reported. However, aqueous-phase detection of Hg2+/TNP by MOF-based fluorescent sensors is limited in the literature, perhaps because of the lack of chemical stability of LCPs in water or in the respective analyte solutions. In furtherance of our quest to devise new LCP sensor materials, herein we report an adenine-based Zn­(II) coordination polymer as a dual detection fluorosensor for selective and sensitive detection of Hg2+ and TNP. Thus, the neutral two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer [Zn­(μ2-1H-ade)­(μ2-SO4)] n (1) with good hydrolytic stability has been synthesized and characterized by various analytical methods, including single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD). We have chosen the biomolecule adenine as a linker because of its multiple N-donor coordination sites and hydrogen-bonding capabilities together with the rigidity of its molecular structure, which can generate topologically diverse MOFs/CPs. The intrinsic luminescence property of this d10-based LCP 1 has been utilized for competitive sensing of Hg2+ and TNP from among a variety of cations and NACs, respectively, by fluorescence quenching. Furthermore, 1-coated paper strips have been developed for visual sensing applications toward Hg2+ and TNP upon exposure to UV light.

elements.content: Adenine (HAde), metal salts, and solvents were purchased from commercial sources. Deionized water was used for synthetic manipulations, and the reagents and solvents were used as received without any further purification. Elemental (CHNS) analyses were done using an elementar vario MICRO cube analyzer. IR spectra were recorded using the KBr pellet method on a PerkinElmer G-FTIR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using Mettler Toledo and Netzsch analyzers. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected using a PANalytical Empyrean (PIXcel 3D detector) system with Cu Kα radiation. SXRD analysis was performed on the crystal structures using a Bruker SMART APEX (CCD) diffractometer. Solid-state UV–vis spectra were recorded using a Shimadzu UV-3101PC spectrometer with BaSO4 as a reference. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded at room temperature utilizing a Horiba Jobin Yvon Fluorolog spectrophotometer. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images were taken using a JEOL JSM-7100F instrument employing an accelerating voltage of 18 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were captured using a JEOL JEM 2100 microscope. The samples were prepared by mounting methanol dispersions on lacey carbon Formvar-coated Cu grids.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

Adenine (HAde), metal salts, and solvents were purchased from commercial sources. Deionized water was used for synthetic manipulations, and the reagents and solvents were used as received without any further purification. Elemental (CHNS) analyses were done using an elementar vario MICRO cube analyzer. IR spectra were recorded using the KBr pellet method on a PerkinElmer G-FTIR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using Mettler Toledo and Netzsch analyzers. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected using a PANalytical Empyrean (PIXcel 3D detector) system with Cu Kα radiation. SXRD analysis was performed on the crystal structures using a Bruker SMART APEX (CCD) diffractometer. Solid-state UV-vis spectra were recorded using a Shimadzu UV-3101PC spectrometer with BaSO4 as a reference. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded at room temperature utilizing a Horiba Jobin Yvon Fluorolog spectrophotometer. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images were taken using a JEOL JSM-7100F instrument employing an accelerating voltage of 18 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were captured using a JEOL JEM 2100 microscope. The samples were prepared by mounting methanol dispersions on lacey carbon Formvar-coated Cu grids.

elements.content: A 15 mL aliquot of an aqueous solution of Zn­(SO4)·7H2O (150 mg, 0.52 mmol) was slowly added to 15 mL of an aqueous solution of HAde (60 mg, 0.4 mmol) in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. The resulting milky-white turbid solution was allowed to reflux at 393 K for 24 h and subsequently to cool to room temperature. Colorless block-shaped crystals suitable for SXRD analysis were obtained in good yield (∼79%). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C5H5N5O4SZn: C, 20.25; H, 1.70; N, 23.62; S, 10.81. elements.content: The aqueous chemical stability of 1 was investigated by soaking the material in water and in aqueous solutions of Hg2+ and TNP. Approximately 50 mg of the sample was dispersed into a 25 mL scintillation vial containing the respective aqueous solution to make the emulsion. The solid material was filtered and removed from the emulsion after 7 days, washed thoroughly with water and acetone, and dried at ambient temperature. PXRD data for the recovered solid samples were recorded to confirm the chemical stability.
elements.clean_text:
Stability Experiments

The aqueous chemical stability of 1 was investigated by soaking the material in water and in aqueous solutions of Hg2+ and TNP. Approximately 50 mg of the sample was dispersed into a 25 mL scintillation vial containing the respective aqueous solution to make the emulsion. The solid material was filtered and removed from the emulsion after 7 days, washed thoroughly with water and acetone, and dried at ambient temperature. PXRD data for the recovered solid samples were recorded to confirm the chemical stability.

elements.content: For the detection of Hg2+ and TNP, fluorescence experiments were performed with 1 in aqueous media with standard aqueous solutions of metal salts (1 × 10–3 M) and NACs (2 mM). For detection and sensing studies, metal ions such as As3+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Cs+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Na+, K+, Pb2+, Co2+, Mn2+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Cr3+, and Hg2+ and different NACs like TNP, 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 2,4-DNT, 4-nitrotoluene (4-NT), 1,3-DNB, 2-nitrophenol (2-NP), and nitrobenzene (NB) were chosen. For the preliminary sensing studies, 2 mg of finely ground 1 was added to a cuvette of path length of 1 cm containing 2 mL of an aqueous solution of cations/nitroaromatics. The emulsion was stirred at constant rate in the fluorescence instrument with a stirring attachment during the whole experiment to maintain homogeneity of the solution. The emission spectrum of each sample was recorded in the range of 330–560 nm upon excitation at 295 nm, and the fluorescence intensity at 395 nm was monitored. All of the titrations were carried in triplicate to establish the consistency of the results. The quenching efficiency was calculated as [(I 0 – I)/I 0] × 100%, where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after addition of the aqueous solution of analytes.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Experiments

For the detection of Hg2+ and TNP, fluorescence experiments were performed with 1 in aqueous media with standard aqueous solutions of metal salts (1 × 10-3 M) and NACs (2 mM). For detection and sensing studies, metal ions such as As3+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Cs+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Na+, K+, Pb2+, Co2+, Mn2+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Cr3+, and Hg2+ and different NACs like TNP, 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 2,4-DNT, 4-nitrotoluene (4-NT), 1,3-DNB, 2-nitrophenol (2-NP), and nitrobenzene (NB) were chosen. For the preliminary sensing studies, 2 mg of finely ground 1 was added to a cuvette of path length of 1 cm containing 2 mL of an aqueous solution of cations/nitroaromatics. The emulsion was stirred at constant rate in the fluorescence instrument with a stirring attachment during the whole experiment to maintain homogeneity of the solution. The emission spectrum of each sample was recorded in the range of 330-560 nm upon excitation at 295 nm, and the fluorescence intensity at 395 nm was monitored. All of the titrations were carried in triplicate to establish the consistency of the results. The quenching efficiency was calculated as [(I 0 - I)/I 0] × 100%, where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after addition of the aqueous solution of analytes.

elements.content: Diffraction data collection of 1 was carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD area detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). Integration of the diffraction data and intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects were performed using the SAINT program. The semiempirical absorption correction was performed using the SADABS program. The structure of 1 was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-2014, and all of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-2014. The hydrogen atoms of the adenine moiety were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. Details of crystal data and refinement parameters and selected bond lengths and angles are provided in Tables S1 and S2.

elements.content: SXRD analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with the P21/c space group and features a 2D coordination framework. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains crystallographically unique Zn2+ ions, one molecule of adenine, and a sulfate anion. The conventionally accepted numbering scheme for chemical and biological purposes has been adopted for the 1H-ade nucleobase. Adenine is a rigid linker with five potential coordination sites, viz., two pyrimidine nitrogen atoms (N1, N3), two imidazolate nitrogen atoms (N7, N9) and the −NH2 group (N10). Adenine can exist in a variety of neutral tautomeric and protonated forms to coordinate with the metal centers. In the structure of 1, the ligand 1H-ade exists as a neutral entity with formal opposite charges on N9 and N1. Migration of the N9 proton to N1 allows 1H-ade to bridge two Zn nodes through the N9 and N7 atoms (Scheme S1). The distorted tetrahedral ZnN2O2 coordination environment around each zinc ion is provided by μ-κN7:κN9 coordination from the adenine moiety through imidazole nitrogen atoms N7 and N9 and μ-κO1:κO3 coordination from the sulfate anions (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal and Molecular Structure of [Zn(μ2-1H-ade)(μ2-SO4)] n  (1)

SXRD analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with the P21/c space group and features a 2D coordination framework. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains crystallographically unique Zn2+ ions, one molecule of adenine, and a sulfate anion. The conventionally accepted numbering scheme for chemical and biological purposes has been adopted for the 1H-ade nucleobase. Adenine is a rigid linker with five potential coordination sites, viz., two pyrimidine nitrogen atoms (N1, N3), two imidazolate nitrogen atoms (N7, N9) and the -NH2 group (N10). Adenine can exist in a variety of neutral tautomeric and protonated forms to coordinate with the metal centers. In the structure of 1, the ligand 1H-ade exists as a neutral entity with formal opposite charges on N9 and N1. Migration of the N9 proton to N1 allows 1H-ade to bridge two Zn nodes through the N9 and N7 atoms (Scheme S1). The distorted tetrahedral ZnN2O2 coordination environment around each zinc ion is provided by μ-κN7:κN9 coordination from the adenine moiety through imidazole nitrogen atoms N7 and N9 and μ-κO1:κO3 coordination from the sulfate anions (Figure S1).

elements.content: As depicted in a, both the adenines and sulfate units act as bridging ligands in the formation of the 2D network oriented in the bc plane. Screw-related Zn2+ ions are tethered by 1H-ade and sulfate anions, producing zigzag chains along the b and c axes, respectively (Figure S2a,b). The Zn···Zn separations through μ2-bridged Zn–1H-ade–Zn and Zn–SO 4 –Zn units are 6.024 and 4.973 Å, respectively. With respect to the nucleobase ligand, the coordinated atoms are the imidazole nitrogen atoms, with Zn1–N7 and Zn1–N9 bond lengths of 2.023(10) and 2.005(9) Å, respectively; these are longer than the Zn–O bond lengths from the sulfate unit, with Zn1–O1 and Zn1–O3 distances of 1.961(8) and 1.994(9) Å, respectively. Angles related to the distorted tetrahedral geometry around the central metal ion in the neutral 2D framework range from 98.5(4) to 125.3(4)° (Table S2).

The Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separations through μ2-bridged Zn-1H-ade-Zn and Zn-SO  4 -Zn units are 6.024 and 4.973 Å, respectively. elements.content: (a) Two-dimensional network of [Zn­(μ2-1H-ade)­(μ2-SO4)] n oriented along the bc plane and (b) observed intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions (N–H···O) between adjacent 2D sheets in 1.

elements.content: In an attempt to understand the supramolecular interaction between the 2D sheets, the packing and hydrogen-bonding interactions were analyzed in detail. Packing diagrams viewed down the c and b axes with hydrogen-bonding interactions are depicted in b and S2c. The 2D nets oriented in the ab plane are involved in intermolecular N–H···O interactions with the adjacent sheets from either side. Thus, the migrated amine hydrogens H1 of 1H-ade make N–H···O contacts with sulfate oxygens O4 of neighboring sheets [N(1)–H(1)···O(4): H(1)···O(4) = 1.85 Å; N(1)···O(4) = 2.712(13) Å; N(1)–H(1)···O(4) angle = 177°; symmetry code = 1 + x, y, 1 + z] on either side, generating a layered hydrogen-bonded 3D architecture. In addition to this, intramolecular N–H···O (amino hydrogen H10) and C–H···O (pyrimidine hydrogen H2) contacts with the sulfate oxygen atoms as well as C–H···N contacts between the imidazole hydrogen H8 and N3 are also observed in the stabilization of the molecule in the crystal lattice. Details of all the hydrogen-bonding interactions with symmetry codes are given in Table S3.

Details of all the hydrogen-bonding interactions with symmetry codes are given in Table S3.

elements.content: [Zn­(μ2-1H-ade)­(μ2-SO4)] n (1) synthesized by the reflux method was subjected to different analytical techniques such as FT-IR spectroscopy, PXRD, TGA, and SEM for characterization and assessment of the thermal/chemical stability and phase purity. The FT-IR analysis of 1 revealed the characteristic peaks of adenine and sulfate. The bands in the range of 3429–3271 cm–1 can be assigned to the υ­(N–H) vibrations: the peaks at 3429 and 3333 cm–1 belong to −NH2 stretching, and the 3271 cm–1 band is assigned to N–H stretching of the heterocyclic ring. NH bending (δ) modes for NH2 and NH moieties of 1H-ade appear at 1688 and 1612 cm–1 and 1550 cm–1, respectively. The aryl C–H stretching frequencies appear in the range of 3161–3079 cm–1. The bidentate mode of sulfate coordination appears in the range 1210–1120 cm–1, and the medium peak at 1148 cm–1 is due to υ­(S–O) vibrational modes (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text:
Characterization and Stability Study

[Zn(μ2-1H-ade)(μ2-SO4)] n  (1) synthesized by the reflux method was subjected to different analytical techniques such as FT-IR spectroscopy, PXRD, TGA, and SEM for characterization and assessment of the thermal/chemical stability and phase purity. The FT-IR analysis of 1 revealed the characteristic peaks of adenine and sulfate. The bands in the range of 3429-3271 cm-1 can be assigned to the υ(N-H) vibrations: the peaks at 3429 and 3333 cm-1 belong to -NH2 stretching, and the 3271 cm-1 band is assigned to N-H stretching of the heterocyclic ring. NH bending (δ) modes for NH2 and NH moieties of 1H-ade appear at 1688 and 1612 cm-1 and 1550 cm-1, respectively. The aryl C-H stretching frequencies appear in the range of 3161-3079 cm-1. The bidentate mode of sulfate coordination appears in the range 1210-1120 cm-1, and the medium peak at 1148 cm-1 is due to υ(S-O) vibrational modes (Figure S3).

elements.content: The bulk-phase purity of 1 was confirmed by comparing the experimental PXRD pattern with the pattern simulated from the SXRD data, which showed very good agreement of the peak positions (). The thermal stability of 1 was also established by TGA and variable-temperature PXRD (VT-PXRD) analysis. The TGA and derivative TGA (DTG) plots disclosed high thermal stability up to ∼450 °C for 1 (Figure S4), which is also substantiated well with the VT-PXRD data (Figure S5).

elements.content: The chemical stability of 1 in water and aqueous solutions of Hg2+/TNP was also examined by soaking the LCP in the respective media for 7 days. The samples of 1 were separated by filtration after 7 days, and the PXRD data were compared with simulated ones based on the SXRD data (Figure S6). Recently, MOFs/CPs have also been exploited as precursors for the fabrication of nanomaterials (metal/metal oxide). Thermolysis of Zn­(II)-based MOFs in the presence or absence of air/N2 results various types of morphological ZnO nanostructures. ZnO is a wide-band-gap (3.37 eV) n-type semiconductor having potential applications in optics, luminescent materials, and catalysis. We synthesized spherical ZnO nanoparticles (NPs) by high-temperature treatment of 1 at 600 °C for 6 h in a temperature-controlled furnace. SEM (Figure S7a) and TEM (Figure S8) images of the ZnO NPs revealed a spherical morphology with sizes in the range from ∼24 to 30 nm. Furthermore, the formation and phase purity of the ZnO NPs was also confirmed by corroborating the peak positions of the PXRD data with those of ZnO from the JCPDS database (JCPDS card no 04-007-1614) (Figure S9) as well as by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) (Figure S7b). UV–vis spectra of 1 and ZnO NPs were recorded in BaSO4 at ambient temperature in the solid state (Figure S10).

elements.content: The photoluminescence properties of MOFs/CPs comprising d10 metal ions and electron-rich multidentate ligands have been explored extensively because of their strong luminescence and potential applications in the field of photoluminescent chemical sensors. The solid-state luminescence properties of 1 and free adenine were investigated at room temperature (). The emission peak for free adenine appeared at 416 nm upon excitation at 295 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

The photoluminescence properties of MOFs/CPs comprising d10 metal ions and electron-rich multidentate ligands have been explored extensively because of their strong luminescence and potential applications in the field of photoluminescent chemical sensors. The solid-state luminescence properties of 1 and free adenine were investigated at room temperature (). The emission peak for free adenine appeared at 416 nm upon excitation at 295 nm.

elements.content: Photoluminescence spectra of 1 and adenine in the solid state (λex = 295 nm). The inset shows digital photographs of adenine and 1 under a UV lamp at 365 nm.
elements.clean_text: 3  Photoluminescence spectra of 1 and adenine in the solid state (λex = 295 nm). The inset shows digital photographs of adenine and 1 under a UV lamp at 365 nm.

elements.content: Compound 1 exhibited a strong emission peak at 413 nm with a slight blue shift relative to the free ligand upon the same excitation. The emission peaks of both adenine and 1 can be attributed to π*−π or π*–n transitions. The emission of LCP 1 could be attributed to a ligand-centered luminescent process on the basis of the almost identical emission peak at a similar wavelength that was observed in the case of adenine. We examined the luminescence of 1 dispersed in commonly used solvents, as depicted in . It was observed that not only the position of the emission band of 1 but also its intensity changes when the dispersing solvent is changed, with acetone as the dispersion medium in which 1 exhibits the weakest intensity.

We examined the luminescence of 1 dispersed in commonly used solvents, as depicted in . It was observed that not only the position of the emission band of 1 but also its intensity changes when the dispersing solvent is changed, with acetone as the dispersion medium in which 1 exhibits the weakest intensity.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence spectra and (b) emission intensities of 1 in different solvents, revealing selective detection of acetone over other solvents.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Fluorescence spectra and (b) emission intensities of 1 in different solvents, revealing selective detection of acetone over other solvents.

elements.content: The PL spectra of emulsions of 1 in different solvents exhibited broad peaks with emission maxima in the range 390–403 nm, similar to that of the solid-state sample. The luminescence intensity of 1 was highest in the case of acetonitrile dispersion and lowest in the case of acetone, i.e., acetone showed the highest quenching. Such a solvent-dependent luminescence phenomenon is of interest for detecting trace amounts of acetone from the above series of solvents. The interactions between the framework and small organic molecules may be the reason for observed fluorescence quenching effect. Upon excitation, energy transfer from the organic ligands to the acetone might take place that could result in the observed fluorescence quenching.

elements.content: In light of the excellent photoluminescence and chemical stability of [Zn­(μ2-1H-ade)­(μ2-SO4)] n , the sensing and detection capability of 1 toward different metal ions in aqueous solution was tested. For preliminary studies, 2 mg of 1 was dispersed in 2 mL of an aqueous solution containing 1 × 10–3 M MCl x (M = Zn2+, Cd2+, Cs+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Na+, K+, Pb2+, Co2+, Mn2+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Cr3+, Hg2+) or As2O3. The luminescence properties were studied by recording fluorescence spectra of the emulsions containing 1 and the respective metal ions upon excitation at 295 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Studies for Hg2+ Detection

In light of the excellent photoluminescence and chemical stability of [Zn(μ2-1H-ade)(μ2-SO4)] n , the sensing and detection capability of 1 toward different metal ions in aqueous solution was tested. For preliminary studies, 2 mg of 1 was dispersed in 2 mL of an aqueous solution containing 1 × 10-3 M MCl x  (M = Zn2+, Cd2+, Cs+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Na+, K+, Pb2+, Co2+, Mn2+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Cr3+, Hg2+) or As2O3. The luminescence properties were studied by recording fluorescence spectra of the emulsions containing 1 and the respective metal ions upon excitation at 295 nm.

elements.content: As depicted in a, the intensity of the emission band at 395 nm decreased considerably upon addition of Hg2+, while other metal ions did not show any radical change. Among different metal ions screened for detection in water by 1, As3+, Zn2+, and Cd2+ showed slight increases in the emission intensity, while the rest of the metal ions showed different degrees of quenching effects, with Hg2+ almost completely quenching the emission band. These results clearly indicate that 1 is a promising candidate for selective probing of Hg2+ in the aqueous phase from among the above-mentioned cationic series. In order to evaluate the sensitivity and quenching efficiency of 1 toward Hg2+, the emissive responses in a fluorometric titration of varying concentration of aqueous Hg2+ (0.05–1.0 mM) against 1 dispersed in water were recorded. As depicted in b, the emission intensity obviously decreased with incremental addition of Hg2+ aqueous solution.

elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Fluorescence quenching for different metal cations in water by suspended 1 (2.0 mg/2 mL). (b) Luminescence responses of 1 (2 mg dispersed in 2 mL water) toward different concentrations of Hg2+ (0.05-1.0 mM) in water.

elements.content: The quenching efficiency was calculated by fitting the fluorescence intensity ratio versus concentration of Hg2+ data to the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation, (I 0/I) = 1 + K SV[A]. where, I 0 and I are the emission intensities of the aqueous suspension of 1 before and after addition of the aqueous solution of Hg2+ respectively, [A] is the molar concentration of Hg2+, and K SV is the quenching constant. As depicted in a, the SV plot is nearly linear over the added Hg2+ concentration range (0.0–1.0 mM), and the calculated quenching constant value is K sv = 7.7 × 103 M–1 with a linear fit coefficient value of 0.9975. In an attempt to determine the limit of detection (LOD) of Hg2+ by 1, the fluorescence intensity was monitored upon addition of very low concentrations of Hg2+ solution (0.1–0.5 μM) to 1 dispersed in water. The LOD was calculated to be 70 nM on the basis of 3σ/m (see section S1 in the Supporting Information). In particular, aqueous-phase detection of Hg2+ by LMOFs/LCPs as fluorosensors is scantly reported in the literature. Important reports on aqueous-phase detection of Hg2+ by LMOFs/LCPs are listed in . Evidently, the present investigation is comparable to previous reports with respect to selective and sensitive aqueous-phase sensing of Hg2+ ions. To determine the ability of 1 to act as a selective chemosensor toward Hg2+, competitive experiments were conducted by addition of 1 mL of Hg2+ (1 × 10–3 M) to 2 mL of aqueous solutions of other metal ions (1 × 10–3 M). The sensing response of 1 toward Hg2+ was almost unaffected even in the presence of added metal ions, justifying its potential for selective Hg2+ recognition (b). Several integrated factors may be responsible for the selectivity for Hg2+ among the group of metal ions investigated. Mercury­(II) ion is well-known for its versatile coordination geometry and high complexation affinity to free sulfur (S) and nitrogen (N) atoms. The free N atoms of the heterocyclic rings and amino functionality on the adenine moieties in 1 are accessible to coordinate with the Hg2+ metal ions. The free basic sites of the adenine molecule (N3 and N10), which are not coordinated to the Zn2+ metal center in 1, can act as binding sites for the added Hg2+ ions possessing versatile coordination geometry. The overall reduction in luminescence intensity upon incremental addition of Hg2+ may be attributed to the coordination of free N-donor sites from the adenine, which may diminish the energy-transfer efficiency of the π–π* transitions.

The strong emission of 1 in water suspension and its thermal, chemical, and hydrolytic stability prompted us to check the sensing of nitroaromatic compounds in aqueous media, which has relevance to environmental and security issues. The photoluminescence spectrum of 1 in water exhibits a strong emission peak at 395 nm upon excitation at 295 nm at room temperature. In order to investigate the applicability of 1 as a promising detecting device for electron-deficient NACs, the fluorescence behavior of 1 in the presence of the NACs was examined. We chose 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 4-nitrotoluene (4-NT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2-nitrophenol (2-NP), and nitrobenzene (NB) for sensing experiments. In order to monitor the aqueous-phase photoluminescence response, aqueous solutions of different NACs were allowed to interact in incremental quantities (0.04 to 0.20 mM) with 2 mg of powdered 1 dispersed in 2 mL of water in a cuvette with constant stirring.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Studies for TNP Detection

The strong emission of 1 in water suspension and its thermal, chemical, and hydrolytic stability prompted us to check the sensing of nitroaromatic compounds in aqueous media, which has relevance to environmental and security issues. The photoluminescence spectrum of 1 in water exhibits a strong emission peak at 395 nm upon excitation at 295 nm at room temperature. In order to investigate the applicability of 1 as a promising detecting device for electron-deficient NACs, the fluorescence behavior of 1 in the presence of the NACs was examined. We chose 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 4-nitrotoluene (4-NT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2-nitrophenol (2-NP), and nitrobenzene (NB) for sensing experiments. In order to monitor the aqueous-phase photoluminescence response, aqueous solutions of different NACs were allowed to interact in incremental quantities (0.04 to 0.20 mM) with 2 mg of powdered 1 dispersed in 2 mL of water in a cuvette with constant stirring.

elements.content: As depicted in a,c, all of the NAC analytes reduced the emission band of 1 to a certain extent, and significant quenching of up to 88% in the case of TNP and up to 33% for 2,4-DNP was observed. The quenching percentages were calculated using the formula [(I 0 – I)/I 0] × 100% and found to be in the following order: TNP > 2,4-DNP > 2,4-DNT > 4-NT > 1,3-DNB > 2-NP > NB (the corresponding quenching percentages were 88 > 33 > 21 > 16 > 11 > 9 > 3). As anticipated, addition of electron-deficient TNP and 2,4-DNP resulted in fast and efficient fluorescence quenching of 88% and 33%, respectively. In particular, upon incremental addition of 0.04, 0.08, 0.12, 0.16, 0.20, and 0.24 mM TNP to an aqueous suspension of 1, the observed fluorescence quenching was 30, 55, 69, 79, 85, and 88%, respectively (b). Interestingly, incremental addition of equivalent amounts of the other studied analytes resulted in relatively low or negligible quenching, as depicted in Figure S13. This result clearly validates the high sensitivity of 1 toward TNP compared with other NAC analytes. The photoluminescence quenching efficiency can be quantitatively explained using the SV equation. As shown in d, TNP at low concentrations displays a nearly linear SV relationship. With increasing concentration of TNP, the SV plot follows a nonlinear pattern with an upward bend. Except for TNP, the SV plots of the remaining NACs under investigation showed a nearly linear relationship upon incremental addition of the corresponding solution. The observed nonlinearity of the SV plot in the case of TNP could be attributable to the occurrence of an energy transfer phenomenon between 1 and TNP. The quenching constant (K SV) calculated from the SV plot for TNP was found to be 3.14 × 104 M–1 which is comparable to the highest values reported by Ghosh and co-workers for selective aqueous-phase detection of TNP using the LMOF [Zn4(DMF)­(urotropine)2(L4)4]. The results of the present investigation are comparable to or better than those of previous reports on some of the recent LMOF/LCP-based fluorescent sensors for aqueous-phase detection of TNP (Table S4). To determine the LOD of TNP by 1, fluorescence quenching was monitored by incremental addition of very low concentrations of TNP to 1 dispersed in water. The LOD for TNP by 1 was found to be 0.4 nM, which clearly validates the excellent potential of 1 as a highly sensitive sensor for TNP in aqueous media (see section S2). To explore the quenching mechanism, normalized absorption spectra of various analytes and the emission spectrum of a water suspension of 1 were analyzed. Good spectral overlap between absorption bands of TNP and 2,4-DNP and the emission profile of 1 was observed, while almost no overlap was observed for other NAC analytes (Figure S14). The spectral overlap in the case of TNP/2,4-DNP advocates a resonance energy transfer (RET) mechanism, which is a long-range process usually yielding considerably high fluorescence quenching efficiencies. In event of contact or vicinity between excited-state LCP 1 and TNP molecules, electron transfer from the conduction band of 1 to the LUMO of electron-deficient TNP may occur, resulting in quenching of the fluorescence. In fact, TNP is recognized to interact favorably with Lewis basic sites because of its acidic phenolic proton. The groups of Zhang and Ghosh demonstrated that free pyridine or pendant amino groups on the crystal surface in MOFs can lead to the sensitive detection of TNP by hydrogen-bonding interactions. The high quenching efficiency of TNP for 1 may be related to the strong electrostatic interactions between the Lewis basic sites (N3 and N10) of the adenine and the highly acidic hydroxyl group of TNP. Thus, highly acidic TNP may selectively interact with the amine group via ionic and hydrogen-bonding interactions for good quenching response. On the whole, the concomitant effects of energy/electron transfer and electrostatic interactions may be the origin of the high selectivity of 1 for the detection of TNP. Competition experiments for selective detection of TNP over the other NAC analytes by 1 were performed by recording the luminescence spectra of aqueous suspensions of 1 in the presence of TNP and other selected NACs. As depicted in a, the results indicated that presence of other NAC analytes did not cause any significant change in the sensing efficiency of TNP by 1.

As shown in d, TNP at low concentrations displays a nearly linear SV relationship. With increasing concentration of TNP, the SV plot follows a nonlinear pattern with an upward bend. Except for TNP, the SV plots of the remaining NACs under investigation showed a nearly linear relationship upon incremental addition of the corresponding solution. The observed nonlinearity of the SV plot in the case of TNP could be attributable to the occurrence of an energy transfer phenomenon between 1 and TNP. The quenching constant (K SV) calculated from the SV plot for TNP was found to be 3.14 × 104 M-1 which is comparable to the highest values reported by Ghosh and co-workers for selective aqueous-phase detection of TNP using the LMOF [Zn4(DMF)(urotropine)2(L4)4]. The results of the present investigation are comparable to or better than those of previous reports on some of the recent LMOF/LCP-based fluorescent sensors for aqueous-phase detection of TNP (Table S4). To determine the LOD of TNP by 1, fluorescence quenching was monitored by incremental addition of very low concentrations of TNP to 1 dispersed in water. The LOD for TNP by 1 was found to be 0.4 nM, which clearly validates the excellent potential of 1 as a highly sensitive sensor for TNP in aqueous media (see section S2). To explore the quenching mechanism, normalized absorption spectra of various analytes and the emission spectrum of a water suspension of 1 were analyzed. Good spectral overlap between absorption bands of TNP and 2,4-DNP and the emission profile of 1 was observed, while almost no overlap was observed for other NAC analytes (Figure S14). The spectral overlap in the case of TNP/2,4-DNP advocates a resonance energy transfer (RET) mechanism, which is a long-range process usually yielding considerably high fluorescence quenching efficiencies. In event of contact or vicinity between excited-state LCP 1 and TNP molecules, electron transfer from the conduction band of 1 to the LUMO of electron-deficient TNP may occur, resulting in quenching of the fluorescence. In fact, TNP is recognized to interact favorably with Lewis basic sites because of its acidic phenolic proton. The groups of Zhang and Ghosh demonstrated that free pyridine or pendant amino groups on the crystal surface in MOFs can lead to the sensitive detection of TNP by hydrogen-bonding interactions. The high quenching efficiency of TNP for 1 may be related to the strong electrostatic interactions between the Lewis basic sites (N3 and N10) of the adenine and the highly acidic hydroxyl group of TNP. Thus, highly acidic TNP may selectively interact with the amine group via ionic and hydrogen-bonding interactions for good quenching response. On the whole, the concomitant effects of energy/electron transfer and electrostatic interactions may be the origin of the high selectivity of 1 for the detection of TNP. Competition experiments for selective detection of TNP over the other NAC analytes by 1 were performed by recording the luminescence spectra of aqueous suspensions of 1 in the presence of TNP and other selected NACs. As depicted in a, the results indicated that presence of other NAC analytes did not cause any significant change in the sensing efficiency of TNP by 1.

elements.content: Moreover, the detection ability of 1 could be restored and recycled after completion of the luminescence titration experiment. For recycling of 1, aqueous dispersions containing 1 and TNP were centrifuged, and 1 was collected by filtration, washed several times with water, and dried at ambient temperature. Remarkably, the initial fluorescence intensity was almost retained even after five cycles, suggesting good recyclability of 1 for detection applications (b). As confirmed by the PXRD data (Figure S15), 1 maintained its crystallinity and structural integrity after five repeated cycles of fluorescence titration experiments with TNP solution. The high thermal/chemical stability and reusability of 1 make it potentially applicable for in-field detection of explosive compounds such as TNP.

elements.content: Detection of Hg2+ ion and TNP by 1-coated paper strips was carried out to explore their utility for in-field practical applications. The 1-coated test strips were prepared by dip-coating of the LCP-dispersed ethanolic solution of 1 on Whatman filter paper strips and subsequent drying in a desiccator. The test strips thus prepared emitted a light-blue color under 365 nm UV light. The 1-coated paper strips were partially dipped into dilute aqueous solutions of all metal ions and nitroaromatics.
elements.clean_text:
Visible Detection by LCP-Coated Paper Strips for Practical Application

Detection of Hg2+ ion and TNP by 1-coated paper strips was carried out to explore their utility for in-field practical applications. The 1-coated test strips were prepared by dip-coating of the LCP-dispersed ethanolic solution of 1 on Whatman filter paper strips and subsequent drying in a desiccator. The test strips thus prepared emitted a light-blue color under 365 nm UV light. The 1-coated paper strips were partially dipped into dilute aqueous solutions of all metal ions and nitroaromatics.

elements.content: The digital photographs of 1-coated paper strips after partial treatment with analyte solutions captured under 365 nm UV irradiation are shown in . As is evident from the figure, emission from the area of the 1-coated paper strips that came into contact with Hg2+ and TNP were quenched significantly (become dark), as could be observed by the naked eye under 365 nm UV light. Test strip experiments with the adenine ligand did not show any appreciable quenching of emission intensity in the presence of effective analytes (Cr3+, Hg2+, 2,4-DNP, and TNP) (Figure S16). This experiment clearly demonstrates the utility of the newly developed LCP [Zn­(μ2-1H-ade)­(μ2-SO4)] n (1) as a dual fluorosensor toward practical applications.

elements.content: The Zn­(II)-based LCP 1 with good thermal and hydrolytic stability has been synthesized by the reflux method from the self-assembly of zinc sulfate with the nucleobase adenine. The neutral 2D framework is composed of both sulfate units and rigid adenine linkers via μ2 coordination with the Zn2+ metal nodes. LCP 1 has been characterized by different analytical methods, including SXRD, and its thermal and chemical stability has been established by TGA and PXRD data. Selective and sensitive detection of Hg2+ and TNP from among various cations and nitroaromatics, respectively, by 1 has been studied. Practically useful 1-coated paper strips for the detection of Hg2+ and TNP that offer visual sensing of Hg2+ and TNP under UV light have been developed. Thus, the present investigation provides a rational strategy for the design and synthesis of a coordination-polymer-based dual fluorosensor for selective and sensitive aqueous-phase detection of the pollutants Hg2+ and TNP, which has significance in the domain of environmental protection and homeland security.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The Zn(II)-based LCP 1 with good thermal and hydrolytic stability has been synthesized by the reflux method from the self-assembly of zinc sulfate with the nucleobase adenine. The neutral 2D framework is composed of both sulfate units and rigid adenine linkers via μ2 coordination with the Zn2+ metal nodes. LCP 1 has been characterized by different analytical methods, including SXRD, and its thermal and chemical stability has been established by TGA and PXRD data. Selective and sensitive detection of Hg2+ and TNP from among various cations and nitroaromatics, respectively, by 1 has been studied. Practically useful 1-coated paper strips for the detection of Hg2+ and TNP that offer visual sensing of Hg2+ and TNP under UV light have been developed. Thus, the present investigation provides a rational strategy for the design and synthesis of a coordination-polymer-based dual fluorosensor for selective and sensitive aqueous-phase detection of the pollutants Hg2+ and TNP, which has significance in the domain of environmental protection and homeland security.

Synthesis of [Zn(μ2-1H-ade)(μ2-SO4)] n  (1)

A 15 mL aliquot of an aqueous solution of Zn(SO4)⋅7H2O (150 mg, 0.52 mmol) was slowly added to 15 mL of an aqueous solution of HAde (60 mg, 0.4 mmol) in a 50 mL round-bottom flask. The resulting milky-white turbid solution was allowed to reflux at 393 K for 24 h and subsequently to cool to room temperature. Colorless block-shaped crystals suitable for SXRD analysis were obtained in good yield (~79%). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C5H5N5O4SZn: C, 20.25; H, 1.70; N, 23.62; S, 10.81. Found: C, 19.09; H, 2.24; N, 22.26; S, 10.19. cln_elements.content:
The bulk-phase purity of 1 was confirmed by comparing the experimental PXRD pattern with the pattern simulated from the SXRD data, which showed very good agreement of the peak positions (). The thermal stability of 1 was also established by TGA and variable-temperature PXRD (VT-PXRD) analysis. The TGA and derivative TGA (DTG) plots disclosed high thermal stability up to ∼450 °C for 1 (Figure S4), which is also substantiated well with the VT-PXRD data (Figure S5).

Photoluminescence Properties

The photoluminescence properties of MOFs/CPs comprising d10 metal ions and electron-rich multidentate ligands have been explored extensively because of their strong luminescence and potential applications in the field of photoluminescent chemical sensors. The solid-state luminescence properties of 1 and free adenine were investigated at room temperature (). The emission peak for free adenine appeared at 416 nm upon excitation at 295 nm.

The TGA and derivative TGA (DTG) plots disclosed high thermal stability up to ~450 °C for 1 (Figure S4), which is also substantiated well with the VT-PXRD data (Figure S5).

Photoluminescence Properties

The photoluminescence properties of MOFs/CPs comprising d10 metal ions and electron-rich multidentate ligands have been explored extensively because of their strong luminescence and potential applications in the field of photoluminescent chemical sensors. The solid-state luminescence properties of 1 and free adenine were investigated at room temperature (). The emission peak for free adenine appeared at 416 nm upon excitation at 295 nm.
